headline.main: STRATFORD'S LAST DINNER.; George C. Boldt to Begin Work on His New Philadelphia Hotel on June 1.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, May 19. -- The last dinner that in all probability will ever be prepared in the Stratford Hotel, this city, was served this evening. This was due to a rather hasty decision on the part of lessee George C. Boldt of New York, who is to erect a fine hostelry on the site of the present structure, to be called the BellevueStratford Hotel.

headline.main: BIG HOTEL FAILS.; The Rittenhouse of Philadelphia Closes Down, Robert M. Blair Making an Assignment.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Oct. 19. -- The Rittenhouse Hotel was closed to-night, much to the surprise of the guests. This action was found necessary as a result of the assignment made recently by Robert M. Blair, lessee and manager.

headline.main: THE BRUNSWICK'S WINES SOLD.; Low Prices Obtained -- The Hotel's Furniture to be Disposed of To-day.

docs.lead_paragraph: The departed glories of the Hotel Brunswick, at Fifth Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street, were brought to mind yesterday, when the entire remaining contents of the wine cellar of the house were sold at auction by Bryan Y. Kennelly of 66 Liberty Street, by order of Joseph H. Baker, the receiver for the Hotel Brunswick Company.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jacob Weissbaum made love to Matilda Walter shortly after their first acquaintance in the November of 1891. A public betrothal was not long in following, the wedding day being set down for the last day in August, 1892. But when the time came Jacob pleaded poverty, and took advantage of his plea to borrow and never return, so she charges, $100 from his fiancee.
